Hello there!

Welcome to my website!

I'm Harley Patton, a third year undergraduate studying Computer Science and Applied Mathematics at UC Berkeley. My interests include machine learning, cryptography, and quantum computing. I work as a researcher for CERN through Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, and as a student instructor for the UC Berkeley Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department. I'm a member of the Nu Chapter of the Upsilon Pi Epsilon Computer Science Honor Society, and a brother at the Cal Alpha Chapter of Sigma Phi Epsilon. I'm a biking enthusiast, an avid reader, and a jazz saxophonist. Click on the links on the left to learn more!

Featured Content

CERN Analysis on PDSF

My repository on the PDSF supercomputer maintained by NERSC (National Energy Research Scientific Computing Center), as part of my work in conjunction with the ATLAS Analysis Team at CERN.

Shor's Algorithm Talk

A talk I gave at the Bay Area Quantum Computing Meetup in August of 2017, describing the math behind Shor's Algorithm, the impact it will have on modern cryptosystems, and demonstrating a toy example that can be run on today's hardware.

QStudio

A suite of tools to make quantum programming more accessible to researchers and the general public. Still a work in progress!
